content:
Posted: August 23, 2014
												This game is--This game makes me feel like nothing else has before. It's a surreal experience in how you never stop learning new things about this mysterious mountain lost in a black void...The way you feel when you start the game for the first time, and you have to do those silly drawings and you have no clue of the implications of them later on.How curious you are at first dawn, when the mountain speaks to you for the first time.When you figure out which keys do what, and why.How satisfying it is to have you first piece of debris hit your mountain.How you get to feel when you figure out how to move that silly piece of crap.When you figure out what goes where and why.When you realize that the mountain is you--You are the mountain, you get to shape the world around you...When you figure out how to play your favorite song on the keyboard.How insignificant you feel when you scroll all the way out, only to see a bloom of light and a dot.The sadness that fills you heart as your first item-- that you became so attached to-- slowly floats off into space, and you cannot do anything.When you have to draw a loved one.When you figure out that you are lost, and the simplist thing like this game can make you find yourself.When you achieve Zen and realize that....Mountain is Love.Mountain is Life.That is what this game is about.

content:
Posted: November 9, 2014
												I don't think a lot of people don't see the value in Mountain, and when people do they tend to simply overcomplicate the game for what it is. It's not meant to be a 'game' exactly. The developers of the game purposefully say this originally: "Leave it open - it's designed to run in the periphery of your life. Only interact with it when you feel like it. You can play Mountain while playing other games. If you are not playing it, it will play itself. ". Again Mountain is just mean to be left open and you can return to it when you feel like it. You might not see the aspect of it originally but you can find it later… hopefully. But then again, what are the standards of a 'game'? Are we to simply segregate Mountain simply because it is possibly outside of the norm? On the contrary! Different experiences lead to different viewpoints which make you more open-minded. So can people truly state that Mountain is not a game but a screensaver? There are many ways to view Mountain and seeing it as a screensaver is one of the more popular demoralizing viewpoints to which many have so acquired. So one can only view Mountain as simply a standalone and not compare it to more contemporary issues. Or one can compare it but by doing so one loses the face value of the game itself. I think I've settled for now the dispute that this 'game' might be a screensaver or simply not a 'game' at all.    On another note, the developers stated this: "If you're having an annoying storm or boring night, play a melody (using your keyboard) and time will accelerate." Mountain is there for you when you decide to return to it and play it. I think that is a common misconception. It's not as much meant to be a 'game' but rather a subsidiary and supporting game next to you. Yet there are many ways to view Mountain as with any form of issue in life. But the Way Mountain was constructed, at times unappealing to the eye, allows it to show you a different path and possibly one you may not have seen before hand.    But you don't have to follow what the developers say. A 'game' is meant to be played whichever way you feel like it. If you feel like you've been cheated off by buying this game, then take two steps back and think about the aspects of this 'game' and the elements. Perhaps you begin to notice that wonderful ambient sound that plays amidst the night, or perhaps you fall in love with the way the streaks of the sun touch your Mountain. But you might not have to like all these things to truly enjoy the game. Perhaps you have all these games and you developed a love for the game. Or perhaps you try to ridicule the game but in turn you've actually Grown accustomed to the game. I for one cannot answer that question of whether a gamer should like this or not, but it is all up to the gamer who buys it, and whether he is willing to open up his heart and mind.    Now is the Mountain truly your Mountain and your own property? I think that is in the conception of the gamer alone for the gamer can make notion whether the Mountain truly is a self embodiment, or the player truly controls the Mountain. Does the Mountain not speak to us and tell us of its thoughts? Or is it conveying a hidden message to where we might be its own spawn and it is the master. Whichever way you see fit, there are quite a lot of ways to see Mountain, as with any game. Mountain might not have a storyline, no shooting, no love triangle (unless you begin to make one up between somehow the items, the Mountain, and the sky in which case you probably might have gone a bit too far), but Mountain contains a moment of solitude in which you might notice things in games that can be recurrent in Mountain. Perhaps Mountain might contain all these elements in which you create the story. Mountain can always be a storyline in which you, the gamer, is going along a path with the Mountain to a destination into your subconscious. There is much to do in Mountain and blocking your imagination and logic will only hinder it. But if you so choose to do so than you have not hurt no one but yourself in denying the possible powers in the 'game' itself. This review cannot display my neutrality toward the game but I only wish to explain to the gamer that Mountain can only be accentuated by only the gamer.    And another thing many question is the role of the keyboard in the game. Although at first it may seem like the keys simply advance time and increase it in a way the human eye can perceive, Mountain is inevitably omnipresent and time is of little importance to him. Binding ourselves to this thought, we can perceive the passing of time as not one full of dread and dreariness, not one full of change and a different scenery, but becoming part of the universe and its infinite realm of possibilities. What we perceive as a minute can seem as nothing more than what has occurred to the Mountain. What we perceive as the future is simply the happening in the Mountain. What we perceive as the past is imply seen as the done by the Mountain.   And another question still remains as to what is the value of the items that the Mountain contains and at times loses. Are those pieces of our memories or life lessons that we must cope to accept? Or are those as somewhat like to put it as simple items that simply 'fall' on the Mountain. No they are granted upon the Mountain and delivered first hand to the Mountain or possibly to you. And what is of this item leaving our grasp and floating off into space? Have we broken your heart, Mountain? Have we done some unforgivable act too which I've lost my pony? That alone can be answered only by the gamer and his affiliation with the mountain.    And what of this inevitable destruction that reaches the doorsteps of the Mountain ever so often. Are we to simply ponder over the oblivion of the Mountain or sputter key notes to protect the Mountain? Or can we observe the Mountain and it's destruction in all its gloom and tidings of change too which a new Mountain is brought forth to bring new waves of joy to the gamer, too which the cycle is repeated. Why do we have the ability to protect the Mountain or is it even in our ability to protect it? Is it predestined that we protected or is it by our own free-will? That is something that neither I can answer you and only you can resolve either by justifying it or believing in something.   This setting that surrounds the Mountain is quite serene and yet the darkness around it is quite opposite. Is this serving as a contrast between dark and light? The battle of how light destroys the darkness. Or perhaps the story has been switched and light is simply a harbinger of this cycle of death that is ever so dreaded upon. Again, I am not in any sort of ability to answer that question, and it alone can be sought through the Mountain.   So if you ever feel hurt or saddened than perhaps a tune on the fashioned keyboard can mend your heart. Or perhaps a stressed out day simply requires a concerto done by your own imagination. And maybe in the end when you've discovered the infinite combinations on the keys that by which you alone and the Mountain as well contains in the hidden locks of memory, you realize all this and then come to think in terms of the Mountain, and how time is not congruent, but simply an assortment of things by which we alone can process and that by which we alone can control. Mountain is infinite and it is up to the gamer only to perceive the game as he wishes.

content:
Posted: May 19, 2015
PRO-GAMER TIPThe Mountain can be used as a screensaver if you rename the .exe to .scr :)tl;dr.The Mountain is constantly changing and metamorphosing. When you stop wanting it to be more than what it is, it blossoms into its own experience.  And what it is, is more virtual plant, than anything else; is that a bad thing? Read on!full review.If you let it, the Mountain can be a soothing and relaxing experience if you need 5-10 minutes (taken) away from your life.  It's a slowly spinning Mountain in Space.  You can zoom out to see nearby galaxies and star clusters, or zoom in to fill your view with the mountain and the surrounding atmosphere.  There are so many variables that change and the changes/additions appear every 30 seconds or so, it has enough to keep your eyes trained and your mind engaged in thought.In a nutshell: if you enjoy sitting on a bench watching nature around you (e.g., the ocean, a coast, a forest, a vista), then you will enjoy this experience.  But understand that virtual-mountain-in-space-watching is the only experience it can innately provide you.  Anything else you experience, is a result of where your thoughts and your psyche take you.  And that's Zen. :)  The Mountain does nothing in particular, but does it very well.PROS+Beautiful scenery/lighting effects+Soothing audio effects+Striking day/night cycle+Well-done weather and season cycles+Occasional random or pseudo-inspirational captions+Occasional random object collisions (some can be quite funny)+Some interactivity (POV, musical keys)CONS-You have to pay for it-Surprisingly resource intensive-wtf, ALT-F4 is how you close it?(suitable for all ages and skill levels)Please hit the like button if you found this review at all helpful.  Thanks :D

content:
Posted: July 24, 2015
AT A GLANCE(Full review follows below) Game Name: Mountain Original Release: 2014 Genre Tags: Experimental; Zen; Simulation; Relaxing; Casual My Overall Grade: B Estimated Playtime (Campaign): N/A Multiplayer Aspect: None Recommended To: Novelty seekers; Casual gamersREVIEWMountain does exactly what it sets out to do.  It is an ambient, casual, silly game that is entertaining to mess around with for an hour or three… and I don’t see the problem with that.  I thought it was very fun.This is a perfect game to combat boredom in a lecture, or a slow day at work.  You can mess around with it a bit and then let it run in the background, so you are free to only partially pay attention to it.  Not everybody at every time is available to get immersed in an epic game; sometimes it is nice to mess around with something light and casual.  This is where Mountain shines brightest.Of note: in order to truly and actively “play” the game, you should probably look up the songs (i.e.: codes) that you can use to force things to happen in the game.  I feel like many people who disliked this game weren’t fully informed of all the things you actually can do to make it more interesting.I don’t normally focus on price in my reviews, because it is all relative.  Many people use Steam; people with a wide variety of incomes and who participate in very different economies.  I will make a brief exception here just to say that I think this game is very reasonably priced. Even at full price it costs less than a soda (at least where I live).  I mention this because I think it is important to recognize that the developers aren’t trying to rip you off; they acknowledge what the game is and what it isn’t, and have priced it accordingly.And so, I believe Mountain is a great little game which should appeal to those of you who may want to casually mess around with it for a few hours here and there.  It certainly isn’t some epic game, but it can be an enjoyable, quaint experience.Follow my curation page to see more of my recommendations!

Posted: August 18, 2014
												This isn't a game, it's a screensaver.From the reviews on the store page, I thought that it would have some kind of events that happen to liven things up. You could grab random objects, arrange them, see the seasons change, maybe there would be some birds flying around. It gave the impression that even though there wasn't a point to the game, the experience alone would be fun, and you'd stick to it just to see what would happen.But I never saw that. I played for 20 minutes. I spun the camera, i played the keytar, I zoomed in and out, I found every feature on my mountain. It rained, i spun the mountain to make the clouds go away. I saw the little thoughts my mountain had. But nothing happened. I pressed every button, manipulated every control I could think of, and made as many patterns with my mouse as I could imagine, and nothing happened.I can't honestly recommend it, because I've had more enjoyment from that Windows '95 screensaver about a maze (with the rat in it) than I did from this game. Maybe there's more to it than I thought, maybe you need to leave it on overnight for something to happen. But it's not presented in a way that makes me want to stick around to find out.

content:
Posted: March 1
												I don't really play video games.  An old shoulder injury prevents me from manipulating a mouse at a computer for longer than what is required for work.  A few weeks ago, I herniated a disc in my spine and was bedridden for several days.  I discovered Mountain.  A video game with no controls.  Initially, I had the same reaction as everyone else.  Neat, a pet rock to check in on occasionally with calm music and ambient sounds!  Perfect!But unlike everyone else, I kept Mountain up at the forefront of my computer screen while I knitted and listened to podcasts.   I interacted with Mountain a lot.  I spoke to it, cared after it like it was a plant.  After 30+ hours of game play, I realized that this game actually has a few delightful little secrets.   You actually do have some control in this game.  The objects that land can be rearranged and moved by clicking and holding on them.  But if you move an object too many times in a row, it can be lost, and too many lost items makes Mountain depressed.  You can also literally shake off clouds.  Mountain is intuitive to your interactions with it.  The more you click on it, the more positive and happy the thoughts are.  I once was rearranging objects and moving and clicking around for a solid 15 minutes and Mountain's response was, "I'm a total babe." Another time, I was rearranging objects and lost a cool item, so I closed out and reopened to the last save, and it responded with, "Wasn't I just here?" Mountain gets depressed and lonely if you leave it alone too long.  It appears that it when you have the game running for several hours, eventually, Mountain starts pulling away from you by zooming out slowly on its own.  If you let it zoom out all the way and forget to zoom in again, Mountain eventually crashes into something fatal.You can also play musical notes with certain keys of your keyboard, and certain melodies will trigger different events.  If you catch Mountain in the midst of crashing into something fatal, you can spam these notes to put up a shield to avoid death. I'm still in recovery now, and will continue to play it, and mess with it, and am excited to see what other secrets this game has to discover.  At one point, Mountain said, "The patterns are hidden.  The game is to help them find themselves."  David O'Reilly once said in an interview: "Everything interacts with itself and everything around it throughout time and space. Everything is also a game, including this sentence, where I can make your eye move left to right, and make sense of these abstract shapes we’ve agreed upon. You’re rendering these shapes into thought on my behalf, it only feels like you’re in control, and you are for the most part, but I’m guiding you, and I want you to keep going, even though you can quit at any time."Mountain is a piece of interactive art.  I'm glad to have discovered it when I did, and in the way that I did, in order to really appreciate what O'Reilly has created.

number of helpful: 181 of 258 people (70%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 23, 2014
												Mountain works well as an artistic statement; it's fairly direct in its questioning of what is/isn't a game but outside of that there is still a lot of fun and humor in the game/non-game. The arts-y side of things: One of the most important aspects of this is the presentation! Mountain first and foremost feels almost like the modern gaming answer to the post-WWI Dada art movement. Where Dada used collages and pre-made works (such as a urinal) and presented them as high art by putting them into galleries in order to challenge the concept of art, Mountain puts itself on the steam store under 'rpg-games' when I think you'd be hard-pressed to find it fitting this term. The 'gameplay' in Mountain is virtually non-existent, since the act of playing Mountain is leaving in on in the background until you hear a sound and can view whatever new content pops up. Like a lot of (post)modern-art Mountain is ultimately making whatever artistic statement you get out of it, there's no real easy answer here.   Ok, but how is the "game" fun?: Well it's pretty relaxing, the visuals are amazingly surreal and serene. There's a lot of goofy items that will periodically crash into your mountain as you leave the program running and your Mountain will often present these funny faux-deep statements about its existence; this effectively works as a way of the game poking fun at its artistic ambitions. While it's hard to say these are of any real substance they're genuinely funny and will at least make you smile reading them. You can check up on your Mountain to see trees grow, seasons pass but the mountain remains a constant.   The only thing that really bothered me about Mountain was the clouds that will clip through the mountain rather than moving around in a way that doesn't make it look so artificial, also some shadow issues happen from time to time. These might seem like minor nitpicks but this can take you out of the expirence.   If you're in the market for a piece of relaxing software that you can leave on while you're working/using the internet/playing other "real" games the Mountain is great, it engages you by being fairly passive. With it being a $1 it's kind of hard not to recommend it to anyone interested.

content:
Posted: August 18, 2014
												It's not a game, so I can't recommend it as a game.  It also uses entirely too many computer resources, to the point that it exceeds some AAA titles.  On some computers, this will cause overheating which is entirely unnecessary in a glorified screensaver.*The game isn't limiting resource usage on its own, so it's causing components to run too hot. It's using more resources than much larger, graphically intensive titles. This is indicative of poor programming, not that any one persons computer is lacking. Any computer would have more trouble running this program than what is reasonable, and it's caused by the same lazy developer who decided to sell a thrown together mess of pretentious bile.  Any attempt to explain what this game is actually trying to say is going to end up being a guess at something the developer doesn't even understand.  A stream of conciousness has never been so dull and pathetically attention seeking, while still managing to turn your room into a furnace.It's unacceptable, and nobody should fall victim to buying this abysmal excuse for a game.If you "play" this "game" as if it were a screensaver, you'll get a somewhat interesting, passive piece of eyecandy that might grab your interest every once and a while

content:
Posted: August 20, 2014
												So I happen to notice this little game, if you can call it that, being played by a friend.  I wondered what in the world it was so was compelled to go check out the store page.  Well to be honest it didn't look like much, a mountain floating in mid air with stuff growing on it.  But hey, at ninety nine cents what can you expect really.  I mean, sure I could have turned that same buck into a tasty cheeseburger or chili dog, maybe gotten a soda or ice cream cone but something made me want to buy this game....  So what did my dollar get me this time??Well so far I've drawn three pictures, and seen a mountain spinning around and around.  Not sure if they all start this way but mine seems to have a bare spot on one side.  I've seen pretty fireflies, watched night turn into day several times, winter came and went, and I've played a few notes on the keyboard as well as seen what the mountain is thinking from time to time.  And that's it, nearly an hour into the game and I've seemingly done all the interactivity you can do with it.  Wait, what's that? I just heard it talk in the background......something about seeing itself in this night.....  Uh..... Is that a mushroom, a red mushroom???  That wasn't there before.... and what happened to that lone shrub that was on the bare side?  Now it's even barer than before.....  And what's this deep rumbling noise I keep hearing??  Like thunder but it's sunny out...  And this, my friends is the lure and fun of Mountain.  Patience and a deep craving to see what happens next and then being in shock and awe when something does happen.  It’s not a high speed, boom, bang game.  It’s  a slow, lazy river kind of game you'll set in the background while doing something else.Did I mention that I love lava lamps?  No really I totally love lava lamps.  What does that have to do with this review??  Well Mountain is kind of like a lava lamp on steroids for your computer.  You don't really do much with it.  Not a lot to play with really.  Oh there are some secret tunes you can play to make things happen but honestly, at the end of the day; this "game" is about leaving it run and seeing what happens from time to time.  And much like the lava lamps in my bedroom you could just sit there watching this mountain spinning around and doing its thing and be absolutely mesmerized with it.  Why?  Because it's simple.  Because it's like life in the fact that you never know what's going to happen next.  Because there's something totally relaxing about it.  Now, if you'll excuse me, it's winter on my mountain and it's totally covered in snow.  Think I'm going to go watch it for a while....  Huh, there's a tiny planet now stuck in the side of my mountain...................weird..............

content:
Posted: August 18, 2014
												It's hard to review a product that only cost 99 cents. But I'll try anyway.First of, this is not a game at all. Now let me describe it in detail so you won't misunderstand.After starting up the game, you will notice that there is no menu or any sort of interface. Instead, you will be asked to draw pictures in a blank white paper. The game then will randomly generate a mountain according to what you have draw (at least to my belief)And what do you do after that? Nothing.What is your goal? There is no goal.You just, stare at the mountain, and that's that. You CAN type certain key on your keyboard to create piano sounds but that's it. The mountain is changing in weather and time which looks nice but it gets old really quick. Music will randomly pop up whenever dawn comes or weather changes or the mountain talks to you.So... yeah. It's not a video game. It's more like a software "labeled" as a game.You just watch the mountain moving, changing, and sometimes talk back to you. The developer could add some interaction to keep the "game" from becoming a boring screensaver. But no, that would be too much to ask appearantly.Do I recommend others to play this? I don't. For a "game" costing only 99 cents, it barely has any content at all. There are some graphical glitches in around the shadow texture and it always makes my dark side of the mountain looks ugly. I don't consider this art because there are more better looking "game" that have the same low price and have better "art".For you people who got an extra 99 cents and wanted a screensaver labeled as a "game", well, here you go.But for me, even at 99 cents, this game lacks content.

Leave mountain running in the background when you play other games, or as a screensaver, and switch back to it and play whenever you feel like. See how your mountain changes as you leave it to discover itself. Come back and observe all the little details. Play with the music keyboard and create an atmosphere for you and your mountain to enjoy. Learn things about your mountain. Learn things about yourself. Become your mountain.

content:
Posted: June 14, 2016
												I got this game with the recent Humble Bundle and thought I would give it a try. Several minutes in, I realized this game was not for me. If you are looking at this game, and you didn't read anything about it yet... there are no controls to this game. You can zoom in, you can zoom out. You can use the some of the keys on your keyboard to type out a bit of a song for the mountain, or for yourself, perhaps because of how bored you are. I couldn't stand more than several minutes of this game, and I think the only reason I made it that long was because I was temporarily amused by the faux-piano. If you get bored easily, this game is not for you. If you like having some sort of control over your games, this game is not for you. If you want to read what the moutain is thinking, and feel some sort of sad emotions or something along those lines, or you enjoy using your keyboard as a musical keyboard, perhaps this game is for you. Personally, for people like me, I wouldn't recommend it.

content:
Posted: January 22
												Mountain is a soothing experience for anyone struggling with anxiety or who just needs a break. To really enjoy what this game has to offer, one needs to have patience and an open mind. Mountain isn't an action-packed, groundbreaking journey; instead, it's a breath of fresh air in our otherwise hectic lives.While the controls are rather self-explanatory, there is a sort of "piano" that players can use within the game. The keys for striking up a tune are A-K and Z-M. I don't believe they have any direct effect towards the gameplay, but they're still fun to mess with.Ultimately, this game is perfect for those who need a little time to wind down and get away from everything.-(2/7/17) EDIT: Apparently playing specific tunes with the "piano" will initiate certain events! Also, "." will ask for the Mountain's thoughts. Thank you @shinymagikarp for letting me know this!

Things die and comeback in time.- Your mountain 'thinks'. (no joke, you can press the '.' key to see what it is thinking)- Things fall randomly? from the sky. (eg. I got a huge record player (phonograph) (edit: HOLY♥♥♥♥♥♥♥classical music is playing from my phonograph :O THIS SONG, a glowing blue black asteroid, clock, bananas etc etc.) - NOTE: These items can be moved around the mountain.- Your keyboard is a piano. THIS. I love this feature. The tune in space is just... I got no words for it. (a positive word not a negative one). If you're not that creative this may be a useless thing but I swear on me mum this is just awesome with the space ambient music. <3 oh yeah...- You can scroll all the way to outer space. (the ambient changes - to a scary feel tune - I think this is to make you feel like you are alone and a lonely mountain in space) but don't expect more than an amazing stary background and rocks(asteroids) floating around.- You can spin the mountain with your mouse. (to change viewing angle)- You can set the screen resolution of the game to a very small window - so it can run in the background + it uses very little memory! (This is for the calm rain/windy effect that is just... no words. It calms you down from all the stress in life - but doesn't solve it ;) )I rate this game 9/10 - and no I'm not joking. This is one of my top most favorite games on steam. But buy with caution though and don't complain afterwards. Know what you are buying -  especially with this game. content:
Posted: January 4, 2015
												Mountain is a semi-interactive screensaver masquerading as a game worth 99 cents. I say ‘semi’ interactive because while the game’s world—comprised of a single mountain dotted with trees, boulders, and random objects—can be spun around, examined from different angles, and viewed from the starlit vastness of space, I always felt distant from what little action I witnessed. The weather shifts from snowy to rainy to sunny whether you’re watching or not; random objects appear without any personal context (I received two trash bins, a bed, and a padlock, amongst others); and when Mountain expresses its thoughts, it does so with little to no awareness of my presence as a player. But according to Mountain’s developer, David O’Reilly, this is sort of the point: “It's designed to run in the periphery of your life,” he writes in an August 2014 update. “You can play Mountain while playing other games. If you are not playing it, it will play itself.” In other words: You don’t really HAVE to play Mountain. Its contents are so inconsequential that it requires only a tiny fraction of your attention. It matters that little. But give me a dollar anyway! Thanks!(Ironic side note: For a game meant to run serenely “in the periphery of your life,” Mountain is a noticeable CPU hog that will likely overheat your computer, especially if you’re using a laptop.)The only thing about Mountain that I found interesting or entertaining was how oddly bi-polar it was. In my hours of game play (or non-play), I began to notice that Mountain’s musings fell into distinct categories, ranging from Dalai Lama-esque mindfulness:“I see great purity in today’s utter perfection.”“I feel at one with the universe inside this foggy winter night.”“What is sadness?”…to a teenage girl’s volatile ‘feels’: “I’m super into this dreamy night.”“I couldn’t care less about today’s rain.”“Maybe I am alone because my rocks are ugly.”…to the nagging of a self-absorbed ex:“I’m a total babe.”“Helloooooo?”Sorta cute, but ultimately, things most people will hear for free. While, you know, living their actual lives. At the end of the day, Mountain falls in line with dozens of other titles lauded by some for pushing the boundaries of what a game can be and crucified by others for daring to call itself a game at all. I tend to side with the latter, though less harshly, as Mountain did serve as a pretty background time-waster for the few hours I played it. Mountain will definitely appeal to collectors of snow globes and people who like half-heartedly watching ennui-rich land masses against a faint ambient soundtrack. A niche market, for sure, but an “experience” some may enjoy.

content:
Posted: September 13, 2014
												This is not a game.  It is more.What is Mountain?By definition a mountain is a large natural elevation of the earth's surface rising abruptly from the surrounding level.But what does this mean exactly?This is a form of art we ourselves cannot comprehend.It may seem like there is nothing, but a mountain may also be described as a large pile or quantity of something.A great deal.A lot.A profusion.An abundance.There is more to Mountain that we cannot understand.Is it in the trees?Is it in the Mountain itself?Do we wait for the weather to change to ask these questions?The subtle piano melody.The scale.The depth.Maybe it's in the clouds which glide over head.It's a metaphor for life.We see little, but there is much more.So I ask you.Or do you ask?"Why spend 99 cents on Mountain?"A synonym I can conjure from that sentence follows:"Why spend 99 cents on the answer to life?"Mountain is the answer to the worlds problems.This is what philosophers have been trying to figure out for years.And these answers are in Mountain.Or is the answer the Mountain itself?I ask one more time.What is Mountain?...That is for you to answer.Or has it been answered already?...Mountain.

Mountain is not a game, as there's no way to play. You have a piano on the ASD... and ZXC... rows of the keyboard (hint to the developers: not everyone has a QWERTY-layout), and by playing, the mountain will rotate faster. That, and moving the camera around it with the mouse, is the only "control" you got in this "game. In a video, I saw someone bouncing a ball off the mountain. I didn't even get to do that.So, why do I still recommend it? Simple: there's a lot of screensavers out there that cost more than 0.99€, but are of much lower quality. So it's got that going for it, which is nice.

number of helpful: 40 of 66 people (61%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 9, 2014
												alright everyone, let me start with an important fact that a lot of people tend to forget, but i think is very pertinent to "mountain":"pretentious"adjective 1. characterized by assumption of dignity or importance, especially when exaggerated or undeserved: a pretentious, self-important waiter.2. making an exaggerated outward show; ostentatious. now before i really begin i would like to debunk something people have been saying about mountain. people seem to find it difficult to categorize mountain, they compare it to a screen saver, they say it "pushes the boundaries of what you consider a game". this is donkey doo because the mountain is not the first of it's kind, it falls into a new genre called "idle-games". the most famous of the idle-games is cookie clicker. idle-games are games you play when you aren't playing games. they usually involve getting points, or some limited range of progression, and are something you come back to on and off during the day.in mountain, you generate a mountain, you let it sit there, you do other things, a pleasant sound runs in the background, and you come back and -- oh my goodness! a pie has found a home on your mountain, and you are very amazed. you realize the keyboard plays different notes on a disembodied piano, and you might even be lucky to discover that playing different songs will do... things.and also -- oh my GOSH! you can move the pie around! and you laugh and cheer and oh my good lord how this is fun!mountain is getting a lot of press and i think it is kind of unfair to much better games of it's breed. there are a lot of idle-games that actually do challenge you to think about what you find fun, and what interests you in a game. i think click-hero is a good idle game, which has you fighting monsters and buying and leveling heroes to make your clicks more valuable. i think cookie-clicker is a testament to the genre, proving how addictive an extra integer can be.mountain does not really do anything for me. if it didn't have objects in it to interact with, it would have nothing, which leads me to believe the creator put the objects in out of necessity. there is little to no progression, the game is poorly optimized, and it's just plain dull and has nothing to show for itself.but, i'm sure, people will tell me how i "just don't get it". i get it.let me tell you briefly how "mountain" could have been an interesting game:as you play mountain, you notice a village of people have built a settlement on the side of you. they seem to be using the resources inside of you for industry, and to great benefit! their cities and town grow as you leave the game running in the background. the sound effects change from peaceful and serene, to a dull chug, a soft clicking of cogs, and eventually the great repetitive doom of heavy industry. The game makes an interesting point, being the mountain, you get no say or interaction in how the people progress. you just watch and observe the people as they grow in populace and in technology until their eventual demise, whether it be by destruction, or the graceful transition from existing, to ascending amongst the stars. either way, you, the mountain, remain, to watch the process happen again.that would have been amazing. that would have made an ACTUAL statement.so, mountain is a dollar. why don't i recommend it? if you want pleasant sounds, go to http://www.rainymood.com/if you want a good idle-game, try cookie-clicker. the beta has a lot of updated mechanics and it's really turning into something amazing. also it's free.if you want a mountain... buy skyrim. it's a game, and debatably fun, plus you climb a mountain!if you want objects, try katamari damacy. it's also a game.save your dollar.

content:
Posted: August 19, 2014
"You are a mountain" That means mountain high loads of fun.You'll be happy after playing this game.For those who ever doubt: "A video game is an electronic game that involves human interaction with a user interface to generate visual feedback on a video device" (Wikipedia)It says involve human interaction, NOT there must be interactivity all the time.Mountain is a self-running natural-like life simulation of a mountain, which floats in a bubble in space. Though it's self running and normally events happen by random you can force him to tell you his thoughts (press "."). Or after pressing certain keycodes special events can be triggered (look the existing guides). Directly you can just spin your mountain view around and zoom in and out per mousewheel. Play spheric piano notes by pressing the keys from "A" to "K" and "Z" to ","His thoughts are kind of philosophic/esoteric. Most amazing are the details in his "mountain life". By night (after 5 min) fireflies buzz around the trees, permanently clouds break at the peak and begin to rain, winter turns in (after 15 min), it begins to snow and wind is howling. The mountain does not only change his face during the playtime, even his underground breaks up and produces some earthquakes. In space there are threaten asteroids flying. And then comes the crazy part. Sometimes objects like a huge clock or an anvil crashes into your little planetoid and remain there. You'll become a collector of unforseen events.Consider you can only loose this game by not noticing its precious uniqueness ...

number of helpful: 8 of 9 people (89%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 8, 2014
												10/10, Amazing, Stellar, Fantastic, 100/100, 5 starts, recmmended by me, my friends, Obama, Osama Bin Laden, Michael Phelps, that one guy who works at Circle K, and Billy. Upon starting up mountain, you are instantly thrown into an intense fight for your life. Never before have I seen such action, adventure, and carnage in one location. My concept of reality and how I view everyday life was completely altered by this game. My balls started filling up with acidic liquid which I quickly found pouring out of my eyelids, which proceeded to burn off, shrivel, and turn into mountains of their own. I started hallucinating and warped to a world where everyone, and everything, was a mountain. The people were mountains, the cities were mountains. I was a mountain, you were a mountain. And upon waking up, I realized I voided my bowels all over my desk chair. Luckily this game comes with a bendy straw, so I was able to drink it all up and proceed to play more mountain. I think the taste of my own excrement inspired creativity, as when I sat down again, I realized mountain comes with a beautiful implemented keytar, which I proceeded to learn to play, and make  my main profession in life. I dropped out of high school so I could devote more time to my beloved mountain. Boss fight after boss fight kept me engaged 24/7, and I had not a reason any more to leave my desk. I decided that I wanted to spend the rest of my life with this game, and made a blood pact with mountain to never leave him alona again, and always be with him. I began to talk to my mountain every night. He never said anything, however I know he understands how I truly feel. I slowly began to become one with my mountain. Whatever it felt, I felt. I had no need for anything else in my meaningless life. My mountain and I evolved to become exalted beings. And we are now constantly in stasis, waiting to be awakened by the deities of the mountain of the ten-fold path. I am happy. Happier than I ever have been. I cannot belive one dollar could enrich my life to this point.I say my last farewell to all that have lived on this earth. I am mountain. You, are mountain.We, are all...Mountain.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2016
An ExperienceAbstractMountain should not be considered a game, it is an interactive piece of art. One that promotes meta-physical philosophical thought, and one that doubles as a relaxing view of an amazing Mountain. The meaning of this isn’t hard to unearth, it only takes a willingness to dig.A truly beautiful game.The PurchaseWhen I first purchased Mountain it was out of curiosity. There seemed to be something that drew me to purchasing it, it was less than a dollar after all.David O’Reilly created an aesthetic for this work that challenged the premise of contemporary art and modern video games. As an artist and film-maker, he ventures far and walks the line of virtual reality and our reality. Mountain is not a game, and nor is it a background program (as many reviewers say it is). It is an expression of the mind, it is a work of art. A critique of Mountain cannot be done from the perspective of entertainment or aesthetics, it must be done from the view of the raw human mind.OpeningOpening Mountain leads directly a blank space framed with a black border. To the top of the blank space, in the frame is written a random word. Mountain then urges a player to “Draw Something”. At face value this seems almost silly, but the randomly generated word isn’t so random. It is something that is a large part of our lives as humans. It begs the question: What does this word mean to us? In my first experience of this, my first word was “Art”. My task then was to create a visual representation of art that fits my definition of what art means to me. After painting in only black and white, the user is prompted to click done. This then repeats for a second and third time. The next drawings I made were of “Fear” and “Confusion”.With progression into Mountain, it is learned that whatever I drew in the beginning had no effect on the mountain itself. As if to hint that whatever those words meant to us, mean nothing to the rest of life. That our lives mean less in the big picture than what we define our lives with.After the three drawings a mountain is generated. With a holy choir note in the background, the user is spoken to. “You are mountain.” says the game “You are God.”“Please Enjoy Your Time Here.”Then I was left with a mountain.MountainIn what seems like an endless endeavor, Mountain rotates in an empty space.With time, day and night will pass, Fall will turn to Winter, and Spring will dry into Summer. Rain will wash down the slopes of Mountain and winds will ruffle the trees growing on the sides.Every once in a while Mountain will think. With a pleasant note, a thought appears on the top of the screen. But this thought is seems empty. It is almost, meaningless in the grand scheme of things. The thoughts of Mountain are small compared to what the situation is.These thoughts are a connection to the daily life of Man. How our small opinions have no real impact on the world around us. When Mountain speaks the thoughts are comments on its current position in the universe.However I would be wrong if I said that all of Mountain’s thoughts are transparent.Some comments paint the grim reality of many people.“Why am I alone?”“I don’t really know what I am”“What Am I? Are you part of me too?” These thoughts appear in between the comments on the warm Spring sun and on the bright blue sky.After observing these more meta-physical questions, the normal thoughts are shown in a new light. It leads to one thinking that these thoughts are all that there is in life, that in an empty and endless world our voice is the only existential connection to our being.But this is idea is quickly brushed away. Maybe there is something else to remind us of our being.Maybe materialistic entities can be our connection to ourselves.So every once in a while, about as often as Mountain thinks, an item falls onto Mountain.The item has no meaning. It just lands onto Mountain, and sits alongside it for the rest of eternity. Some of these items are references to previous works by O’Reilly.Early in my experience I was pleased to learn that pressing different keys caused a different musical note to play. If played in specific orders, those resembling main melodies to famous pieces of music, an effect will happen. The connection of the action done and the song is up for interpretation, and can be seen differently by different people. The combinations so far act as entertainment, but to each person his own analysis of the music.Besides musical tones played at the users command, there are ambient sounds to accompany the experience. Crickets at night and the sound of wind create a mood of relaxation and peace. This harmony is the true experience of peace for most of our lives, or to many, the external façade of peace, a mask of stress and pain. The calmness is almost surreal in this context.After a random amount of time, Mountain will end.The player can force it with the musical tone aforementioned, and a randomly generated object will collide with Mountain, ending it (It is said however, that with spamming musical notes, this can be avoided, almost as if we can postpone death with meaningless, or to some, meaningful, noise).Or Mountain will reach a more natural ending. And a message will appear describing the death of Mountain.The message can be natural, that Mountain was ruined by a passing sun.Other deaths are less natural, that I, Mountain, died to Rupert, The Bringer of Ice.In essence, Mountain is an experience, not a game.An Experience that is unique, special, and a reflection of who we are.

content:
Posted: October 12, 2015
This review is created for  My Curation Page.   I received this game for free, however, my review is unbiased You are Mountain. You are god.Mountain is a strange product on Steam. Note I said the word "product", not "game.This product is not a game. "Mountain" is an experience.GameplayFor the very low price of $1.09, I highly recommend you purchase it. Mountain is not a game where you actively participate, instead you keep it running in the background, or perhaps as a fancy wallpaper. There are 2 ways you can interact with your Mountain. You can:A) Spin in around in circles.B) Use your keyboard as a piano. There are many guides on how to make your own music.As you run Mountain in your background, occasionally switching back to the Mountain window to inspect any changes, you will notice trinkets that have crashed into your mountain, such as a plane, or perhaps a ball. However, if you don't give your mountain enough attention, such as occasionally playing a few random notes, or spinning your mountain, you will notice the trinkets you amassed over the hours begin to disappear off your island, as mysteriously and quickly as they arrived.The next "obstacle" you may come across is a "meteorite" hurtling across the vast emptiness of space, directly at your mountain. There are 2 possible outcomes: You play a jumble of random notes and evade the impending doom, or accept your fate and watch on in horror as your mountain is obliterated into nothingness.Final ThoughtsIn conclusion, Mountain is a great product on Steam, and if you are looking for something new and different, look no further then Mountain. Observe your mountain change and amass a collection of trinkets. Pros of Mountain:Relaxing AtmosphereNo skill requiredFancy WallpaperAmass a collection of trinkets for hoarders all over the EarthCasual "Gaming"Interesting experienceCons:No music (You must create your own)Very limited action (The only action is the "meteorite" that comes once in a blue moon)Will become old VERY fast6/10Enjoy the review? Please check out  My Curator Page  as well as my  YouTube Channel .

number of helpful: 12 of 18 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 18, 2016
												"Mountain" is not a game. It should have been produced as a screensaver, because that is what this is. It shows a mountain on the screen, which slowly rotates, while sun comes up and goes down and sometimes weather changes. You may type things on the keyboard, but the only effect is that after you typed a period, a random sentence is shown at the top of the screen. You may use the keyboard to play the piano, which is the best feature of this program.I have heard some people rave about "Mountain". I have no idea why. It is less interactive than a Tamagotchi. I let the program run for over an hour, and absolutely nothing happened. Controls there are none.Do I recommend "Mountain"? Here's the thing: it is excellent for what it tries to be, so if what you are looking for is a screensaver that you can watch and contemplate, then "Mountain" is a great choice. But if you want to play a game, then by all that is holy give it a miss. It isn't worth the 99ct asking price,I do understand that if you wait really, really long, you might see a random object impact your mountain. But that did not happen within an hour, so I killed the mountain by launching a meteorite. At least something happened.

content:
Posted: August 25, 2014
												I was there floating in space, going through the wonders of fall. I loved watching my leaves change. Out of nowhere, a large object speeds towards me. "Mother of God", I shouted. After building a shield of melodies, it continued to move closer to my mountain. It penetrated my tightly knit landmass, and stayed there. The object was a fork. THis was my only friend, I never thought I would meet any friends in space. We laughed at eachother, but then we got in a small fight. I crate had landed on the other side of me, and the fork did not like him. I decided that they needed to get along. I pushed the fork from my dirt, and moved him to the crate. Whilst moving him, I hit the wrong melody key, and lost all strength in my meditation. The fork fell from my theoretical grasp, and into space. He floated for days until I could no longer see him. Now all I have is a crate.Also, please add co-op in which two people can watch the same mountain, and play the keyboard together.

content:
Posted: December 16, 2014
												山 顾名思义,一种自然环境，地理面貌。这游戏节奏很慢，也没有强烈的目标性，就是看着你的山一点一点完整起来，但是我觉得这个游戏带给我们的并不是单纯的喜+1。也许从游戏内容角度上来说，这游戏非常简单，挂机看景色变化，等待不同物体的出现，然后输入输入作弊码让天下下桃心之类的...但是我觉得其实这游戏最关键的部分在于一开始让你画出的3幅图画上！如果说人类的思想是创造的根源，那其实你所谓的天马行空，也是离不开你本身的所见所闻，而无限发散的。而这游戏所造成的影响，就是暗示了...暗示着你画的图案跟山的构成，物品的种类密不可分；暗示着一切的发生都是因果循环...正所谓道生一，一生二，二生三，三生万物也不过如此。三张图定型了一座山的发展也不再显得那么突兀。也有人把这个游戏上升到洗脑神教的层面了,我觉得怎么说，这种类型的游戏很少，大家喜欢就好，如果山能在你心中成为一片净土，又有什么不可以呢？！人家刚刚被我大山教洗脑了，所以一点都不萌萌哒，大家不要介意！！嗬嗬嗬嗬,所以，综上所述！我的结论就是买！买！买！

content:
Posted: September 22, 2014
												This game is an existential crisis simulator. The only real control you have over this mountain is to smash the keys on your keyboard to make noise (or music if you're so inclined - I think you could play most of Claire de Lune if you were skilled enough), which has the effect of making time move faster. You spin faster and seasons come and go in seconds. But what is the point? What meaning does time have to you? You're just an immortal lump of space rock, slowly acquiring meaningless knick-knacks. Time is endless and without purpose to you, so despite being able to control time, you still can't control your life. That being said though, this game bored the hell out of me. It's definitely much more than a screensaver, but that doesn't make it any more entertaining than one.  7/10

Posted: December 23, 2015
												My pet rock is jealous and has left me. I do not care, however, my rock companion of 10 years pales in comparison to Mountain. Mountain makes me feel safe. Mountain is more than a game. Mountain is more than a simulator. Mountain is more than a companion through life. Mountain is part of you. You stare at Mountain, Mountain stares back. You exit Mountain, Mountain is still there. You exit Steam, Mountain is still there. You divorce your spouse, there is no other but Mountain. You die, Mountain is there. You go up, but not to heaven, why would you go to heaven when there is Mountain? You drift through the cosmos alone, but you are not alone, Mountain is watching you. You call to Mountain, and Mountain comes to you. You hug Mountain, Mountain hugs back. You become part of Mountain. Mountain is you, you are Mountain. Mountain has never left. Mountain is never going to leave. Mountain is forever.

												This game is soothing, not something you play, not something you try to win, or end up losing.When I picked it up, it was nothing more than a waste of space in my library, never played it, but I decided to try it out, and when I did, man was I wrong about it being a waste of space. It made me happy watching my mountain go through the seasons, or see items falling down onto it, the atmosphere made it feel like it was alive, seeing my mountain think made me happy, it would have sad days, or happy days, but in the end - it was my mountain.Pick this game up if you need something to help relax.

content:
Posted: September 24, 2015
												This game has a rich and deep storyline. It is an amazing game that words can't describe. It explores the deep secrets of life. It makes you question reality. Who are you? Why do you exist? What are we? I've been searching for a good game to actually play. I have been getting bored of most games. Too much tf2 and Csgo. I need a new game. Mountain is that game. Mountain is amazing. You just have to play the games to understand. I have been going through depression and didn't know what to do with my life. But this game saved me. It saved me from everything. I had almost choked. But this game came in and gave me cpr. This game saved my life. This is the best thing to ever come into existance. This game can do everything and has the answer for everything. It cured my Grandpa's kidney stones. It cured my dad's smoking habits. It cured my Asian eye problem. It cured my sister's hearing problem. It cured my mom's cancer. This game had brought me and my family closer together. I don't think I can thank this game enough. Even though I don't have that many hours in this game, I think this is just the start of an amazing and beautiful future. But the question is.Do I reccomend this game? Yes. I give it 30 tf2's out of 10 csgo's. It is that good.

content:
Posted: August 19, 2014
												A wise man named William Shatner once said “Why do I climb the mountain? Because I’m in love!” I understand these profound words more than ever, it’s all clear now as I watch the indolent mountain spin and the rain come and go. My deepest urges to climb, hug and envelop that mountain and yet it cannot be … this embrace is but an illusion. No matter how hard I try to be near you I am but pushed further back into the stratosphere to watch you from afar. You speak to me and I listen to your sweet harmonics yet I cannot answer back, no words can answer your call … yet still I heed.So you may be asking why? Why do I continue to watch the mountain? It’s simple.Because I’m in love.

number of helpful: 11 of 17 people (65%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 2, 2015
												I used to be an adventurer like you, then I took a copy of Mountain from a friend.At first when getting it installed, I was shocked by how fast it was done. It was superfast, only 1 hour. (You can't imagine how I am tortured when getting other games installed.) And like a miracle after I click the "PLAY" button it only takes 4 secs for the game to start. So it must be a good choice for those whose PC or Internet environment is not so good.While the required space of Mountain is only 200MB+, it features tremendous in-game contents. And thanks to the awesome producer for not selling DLCs so we can enjoy all of it costing only 1 USD.Its graphics always make me bewildered (in a good sense). During the xx hours playing Mountain I never get bored and I will keep playing it until I reach my, let me say, sixties. Just watch some videos of this game (I'm quite sure there are a bunch of them out there), you can find those beautiful twinkle fireflies, mighty peaceful pine trees, howling freezing blizzard (actually there's no sound effect for the snow, just imagine it in your brain), and stuff.Everything is modified delicately to make this game so perfect. In my life so far, I've only got a similar feeling when watching a legendary Japanese artisan doing his works. This game is trying to lay out to gamers the beauty of the wonderful nature and humanity. No wonder many friends of mine just told me that their minds were purified and enlightened through meditation right in front of this game.However, what attracts me most is that it has a in-game 16-tone virtual instrument. Comfortably sit back and hit your keyboard and you will feel like playing a real instrument. Personally I strongly recommend the game company release a VST version of this game so that gamers could produce music by simply applying it to their DAW/DTM.Mountain randomly gives out background sounds, useful items and important comments to the gamer, so it's also interesting to watch your mountain revolving while waiting it to have some new changes.Until now I haven't got this game cleared once. I have no idea about how to finish the game, either. But I'll let it go.I can still recall what the game said in the first place:　　　YOU ARE MOUNTAIN. Yes, I am mountain and I am this endless universe. I'll just keep on playing Mountain and playing as a mountain. So maybe by and by the game will end someday, and that will be the end of my boring life.

content:
Posted: November 9, 2016
												Now, there's not really much to this, but I'd still recommend it. First thing: gameplay is almost non-existant, so I'll refrain from calling this a game.The visuals of this program are pretty impressive, even if they are simple at times. On the lowest settings (which I usually use since my computer isn't really a "gaming" computer), it almost looks like a watercolour painting that you can interact with.As I said before, gameplay is lacking. What isn't, in my opinion, is sound. Users can make music with the keyboard, and can play around with it to make or recreate little songs. Some specific songs give interesting effects or filters to the world, like raining blood or frogs, or even "snowglobe mode."I'd say it's a neat little program and deserves a place in anyone's library, especially if they enjoy just sitting around and watching things change around them. A lot like Viridi, but without the daily upkeep that it needed.

content:
Posted: August 31, 2015
												Mountain is an experimental artistic game. It doesn’t have gameplay, story or even genre. You get to be a mountain, you can play the piano with your keyboard and some songs unlock events and Easter Eggs.As time passes by, the seasons change, oh and you get hit by objects that get stuck within you. Not sure how many, but I've been hit by a plane, a paper plane, a beach ball, an umbrella, a giant skull and a lot of other random stuff.It's not going to change the industry, but if most developers started thinking outside the box, like David O'Reilly did here, we could finally play something really new. I mean, no genre, not gameplay, no standard. Only different and new.Seems I was quoted by PC Gamer[web.archive.org], I feel humbled.★★★★☆ | Liked it------------------------------Old ReviewMountain is a game in its roots. It doesn’t have all those preconceptions of what a game should be or have, it tried something totally new. When you read 'game' you usually think on graphics, gameplay, story and genre. But a game shouldn’t necessarily have those; games are ways of entertainment. There's no rule saying it should have good graphics, any story at all or even controls, as long as it entertains people. This game has no story, no controls, not genre. It's an experiment made to entertain without those, and I found it, personally, entertaining. It’s not going to change the industry, but if most developers started thinking outside the box, like David O'Reilly did here, we could finally play something really new.As for those looking for gameplay, play the pianno (you can play a pianno with your keyboard in the game), something might happen.

Posted: August 27, 2014
												THIS IS NOT A GAMEBUY THE♥♥♥♥♥♥OUT OF IT!!!!Seriously, best dollar I've ever spent.  Seriously!  Ever gone to a mall, or a garage sale and seen a sweet lava lamp and you're like DAMN IF I DID DRUGS I WOULD CERTAINLY LIKE THIS FINE LAVA LAMP!  But then you notice it's obscenely overpriced and you're like Nahh whatever I'll just save my money to do more drugs?Well, this is not a game, this is a $1 lava lamp that talks to you and floats through space.It kicks♥♥♥♥♥  You float through space, it looks pretty.  Game over.  You don't play it you set up a random seed and watch it evolve over time on a space monitor.  Occassionally you hear a faint ping followed by a thought from the mountain.  That's right, your mountain talks.  Not too much, mostly likes to sit there in silence.  Perhaps it's trying to be a good listener too?  Perhaps it's just pretending to be listening?  Who knows, it's a mountain and a couch just hit it.  What are you going to do now?

number of helpful: 7 of 10 people (70%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 11, 2015
												This is an interesting experiment. it really isnt a game per se, but it is well worth the dollar you will spend on it. It is as the title says....a Mountain, which is a god, a single great entity, and being that is finding a sense for itself and asking the basic questions beings ask themselves...why am I, who am I, am I alone, and so on. While this is happening, weather changes, day and night cycles, and random objects crash into its surface. You can use the keyboard to craft/play songs, many of which unlock various weather and artifact features, thoughts, and so on. I recommend leaving this game open and checking on it every so often to see what it is doing and has done while you were away.When you grow weary of it, you can destroy your mountain, wipe its surface clean, or whatever.This is something people should be experiencing. A simple and yet deep experience.10/10

content:
Posted: July 9, 2016
												Changed my life in more ways than one. I don't want to go anywhere or do anything because I just want the Mountain. I went out and bought a 1,200 USD laptop to play the Mountain on. I have heard that this game brings the most joy when played at 3000 FPS. I installed a large battery bank into my car for the low price of only 3000 USD. Why would I need something like that in my car? The answer is quite simple really so that my laptop can always be charging to play the Mountain. You may ask, "Why is that you only have 23 hours in the game but have dedicated this much time and effort to play the Mountain"? The answer, again, is really quite simple, jimmy. The game is such a rush that I have to control the amount I'm exposed to it. I'm afraid I may become addicted to this masterpiece and end up in a rehab. I'm already getting looks from people because I had to stop paying rent to pay for the battery, car, and laptop. I live in my car now, but don't feel sorry for me;feel sorry for yourself because you haven't felt the rush that this game offers.20/10

content:
Posted: December 6, 2014
												This is not a "game" at all. It is a joke. I mean that literally. It is a joke on all of us, and I fell for it.We have a stupid, meaningless introduction, then a disjointed mountain, spinning in space, with some mystical atmosphere about it. The graphics are horrible. Throw in a random, nonsensical, useless quote or a random string of text once in awhile. Aaaaand... That's pretty much it.Basically, you could crap in a plastic bag and create as much value and worth as this "game". Actually, that would be an improvement, because no one would waste their time or money on your creation, unlike this "game"."Leave it running." Sure, but do note it takes several hundred MB of RAM and no small amount of CPU time.The AppData folder and registry key created by this game are named "Trash". That's absolutely appropriate.I wish there weren't so many idiots who desperately tried expressing how clever they are by creating sarcastic, ironic, or otherwise insincere "reviews".I paid $0.66 and still feel ripped off. I guess the joke's on me.

content:
Posted: August 24, 2014
												Most of the people I meet on Steam don't remember the 90's too well or are children but back then people were obsessed with screensavers, useful programs that prevented CRT phosphor burn-in. Once in a while you had some naive user download a malicious program under the guise of a screensaver, unaware elders and parents would fall for this not knowing the danger and next thing you know, you'd have your family screaming about thousands of dollars in charges on their Visa card originating from some former Communist country which causes the bank to close your account and force you or your loved ones on the street.This ladies and gentlemen better have been the screensaver that screwed them over.TL;DR: It's not a game but screen candy and ain't half bad at being so.

content:
Posted: September 8, 2015
												Mountain. What can I say about mountain?Mountain is... well, Mountain. You dont play Mountain. You don't do Mountain. Mountain is just there. It plays itself. You open it, and you let it sit there. And Mountain does whatever mountains do.When I first started the game, I thought it was cool, a neat idea. A game that plays itself, something that you have no interaction with. It runs in the background, and you forget about it. Then you hear a *ping*. You look back to the window and it has a thought. Nothing big, but something to keep you interested. "I could write a book about this pitch black night." is an example.You become attached to Mountain. It becomes your mountain. Mountain is not a game. It's an experience. 10/10

												Mountain is a wonderful game man. Sometimes i can get really angry you know? When i play this game, i can never help but smile and feel happy. Most of the time i take the game for granted but when i reach deep down i know that without this game i would not be the person i am today. Honestly some of my most life changing moments were a result from me playing this game and having a realization. Purity would be the best word i can define this game as for it is not only a game but a part of you that you can access in a virtual way. The subtle sound of waves and wind in the in game sounds help me with my relaxation of my body. Knowing that i have this game at my disposal only makes me cherish it more because of the fact that there will never be another groundbreaking game like this. The simple aspect of the mountain in the sky opens up a ♥♥♥♥ing plentiful of eyeopening and astonishing thoughts that i have never experienced in my life before. Without extending this review to an uncalled for extent i would just hope that you people out there with any type of lifestyle ranging from happy to sad should definitely buy this game. Please have a wonderful day and enjoy the simpler things in life. Amen. I love you.

content:
Posted: August 24, 2014
												A mountain is a large landform that stretches above the surrounding land in a limited area, usually in the form of a peak. A mountain is generally steeper than a hill. Mountains are formed through tectonic forces or volcanism. These forces can locally raise the surface of the earth. Mountains erode slowly through the action of rivers, weather conditions, and glaciers. A few mountains are isolated summits, but most occur in huge mountain ranges.High elevations on mountains produce colder climates than at sea level. These colder climates strongly affect the ecosystem of mountains: different elevations have different plants and animals. Because of the less hospitable terrain and climate, mountains tend to be used less for agriculture and more for resource extraction and recreation, such as mountain climbing.The highest mountain on Earth is Mount Everest in the Himalayas of Asia, whose summit is 8,849.868 m (29,035 ft) above mean sea level. The highest known mountain on any planet in the Solar System is Olympus Mons on Mars at 21,171 m (69,459 ft).DefinitionThe Matterhorn, Swiss AlpsDôme du GoûterThere is no universally accepted definition of a mountain. Elevation, volume, relief, steepness, spacing and continuity have been used as criteria for defining a mountain. In the Oxford English Dictionary a mountain is defined as "a natural elevation of the earth surface rising more or less abruptly from the surrounding level and attaining an altitude which, relatively to the adjacent elevation, is impressive or notable."Whether a landform is called a mountain may depend on local usage. The highest point in San Francisco, California, is called Mount Davidson, notwithstanding its height of 300 m (980 ft), which makes it twenty feet short of the minimum for a mountain by American designations.[citation needed] Similarly, Mount Scott outside Lawton, Oklahoma is only 251 m (823 ft) from its base to its highest point. Whittow's Dictionary of Physical Geography states "Some authorities regard eminences above 600 m (2,000 ft) as mountains, those below being referred to as hills."In the United Kingdom and the Irish Republic, a mountain is usually defined as any summit at least 2,000 feet (or 610 metres) high, whilst the official United Kingdom government's definition of a mountain, for the purposes of access, is a summit of 600 metres or higher. In addition, some definitions also include a topographical prominence requirement, typically 100 or 500 feet (30 or 152 m). For a while, the US defined a mountain as being 1,000 feet (300 m) or taller. Any similar landform lower than this height was considered a hill. However, today, the United States Geological Survey (USGS) concludes that these terms do not have technical definitions in the US.The UN Environmental Programme's definition of "mountainous environment" includes any of the following:    Elevation of at least 2,500 m (8,200 ft);    Elevation of at least 1,500 m (4,900 ft), with a slope greater than 2 degrees;    Elevation of at least 1,000 m (3,300 ft), with a slope greater than 5 degrees;    Elevation of at least 300 m (980 ft), with a 300 m (980 ft) elevation range within 7 km (4.3 mi).Using these definitions, mountains cover 33% of Eurasia, 19% of South America, 24% of North America, and 14% of Africa. As a whole, 24% of the Earth's land mass is mountainous.GeologyMain articles: Mountain formation and List of mountain typesJeff Davis Peak seen from the glacier-carved summit of Wheeler Peak, NevadaThere are three main types of mountains: volcanic, fold, and block. All three types are formed from plate tectonics: when portions of the Earth's crust move, crumple, and dive. Compressional forces, isostatic uplift and intrusion of igneous matter forces surface rock upward, creating a landform higher than the surrounding features. The height of the feature makes it either a hill or, if higher and steeper, a mountain. Major mountains tend to occur in long linear arcs, indicating tectonic plate boundaries and activity.VolcanoesMain article: VolcanoGeological cross-section of Fuji volcanoVolcanoes are formed when a plate is pushed below another plate, or at a mid-ocean ridge or hotspot. At a depth of around 100 km, melting occurs in rock above the slab (due to the addition of water), and forms magma that reaches the surface. When the magma reaches the surface, it often builds a volcanic mountain, such as a shield volcano or a stratovolcano. Examples of volcanoes include Mount Fuji in Japan and Mount Pinatubo in the Philippines. The magma does not have to reach the surface in order to create a mountain: magma that solidifies below ground can still form dome mountains, such as Navajo Mountain in the United States.Fold mountainsMain article: Fold mountainsFold mountains occur when two plates collide: shortening occurs along thrust faults and the crust is overthickened. Since the less dense continental crust "floats" on the denser mantle rocks beneath, the weight of any crustal material forced upward to form hills, plateaus or mountains must be balanced by the buoyancy force of a much greater volume forced downward into the mantle. Thus the continental crust is normally much thicker under mountains, compared to lower lying areas. Rock can fold either symmetrically or asymmetrically. The upfolds are anticlines and the downfolds are synclines: in asymmetric folding there may also be recumbent and overturned folds. The Jura Mountains are an example of fold mountains.Block mountainsMain article: Block mountainsThe Catskills are a dissected plateau.Block mountains are caused by faults in the crust: a seam where rocks can move past each other. When rocks on one side of a fault rise relative to the other, it can form a mountain. The uplifted blocks are block mountains or horsts. The intervening dropped blocks are termed graben: these can be small or form extensive rift valley systems. This form of landscape can be seen in East Africa, the Vosges, the Basin and Range province of Western North America and the Rhine valley. These areas often occur when the regional stress is extensional and the crust is thinned.ErosionMain article: ErosionDuring and following uplift, mountains are subjected to the agents of erosion (water, wind, ice and gravity) which gradually wear the uplifted area down. Erosion causes the surface of mountains to be younger than the rocks that form the mountains themselves. Glacial processes produce characteristic landforms, such as pyramidal peaks, knife-edge arêtes, and bowl-shaped cirques that can contain lakes. Plateau mountains, such as the Catskills, are formed from the erosion of an uplifted plateau.ClimateMain article: Alpine climateA mountain in Carbon County, UtahThe Rockies - Valley of the Ten PeaksClimate on mountains become colder at high elevations, due to the way that the sun heats the surface of the Earth. The sun warms the ground directly, while the greenhouse effect acts as a blanket, reflecting heat back towards the Earth that would otherwise be lost to space. The greenhouse effect thus keeps the air at low elevations warm. As elevation increases, there is less greenhouse effect, so the ambient temperature goes down.

When I was a child, My parents moved to a new place for their jobs, so I just went to a new school. But nobody knows cause I always pretended I was a happy guy and I told my parents that I made a lot of friends in my school. But in fact, I cried after everybody went to sleep.       After my freshman year in high school, we had 2 months of summer holiday so my parents sent me to a summer school which was located in a small town in England called Hastings. It was actually great because I went there with my father's friend's relates. In the camp I met a girl from Ukraine. She was beautiful, but I was just an fat and ugly boy and I didn't dare to talk to her. We were in different summer camps but our schedules was same (Which means we would meet everyday). But in the summer camp everybody treated me nice and I talked a lot to my friends. I became a out-going person after I went to the camp. It really changed my life. I saw my mountain got destoried by meteorites just like my heart got tore apart when I saw my dream girl became a ♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥♥♥.  Mountain isn't a normal game. It's more like epitome of my life. Like a tomb of my love.

content:
Posted: August 18, 2014
												Let's be clear here: a lot of people are not going to like this game.  Many won't even consider it a game.  But whether Mountain is a "game" or whether it's worth $0.99 isn't important.  It doesn't matter if there's a lot to do, or nothing to do, or whether there's even a point to whole thing.  And some of you will probably think this review is just as meaningless.  "It's just a bunch of existential nonsense.  This game is stupid and you're stupid."  Well that's okay, because I like this game.  Mountain is for me what it can only be for ME.  It's beautiful, relaxing, thought-provoking.  It's powerful.  It's moving.  But most important... Mountain merely "is."  There is you, there is the mountain.  You are the mountain.  And if that isn't enough for you, then that's fine.  But I implore you to really try to experience what you've purchased before rushing to judgment.  Because in the end, the Mountain doesn't care what you think of it.  And neither should you.
